question_details.query: What are the effects on butterfly and moth communities of opening up forest canopies through clearing, coppicing, or thinning?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, opening forest canopies by clearing, coppicing, or thinning commonly increased butterfly richness and/or abundance, while macro-moths often declined relative to closed or mature forest. Cleared patches had higher butterfly species richness than unmanaged or closed-canopy areas, but lower moth richness; larger clearings supported higher butterfly richness and abundance than undisturbed forest, and wider rides had lower macro-moth abundance than standard-width rides or mature forest; butterfly richness and abundance sometimes declined over the first three years post-clearance, and some species’ abundance peaked 2–4 years after clearance (3938). Thinning (often alongside prescribed burning, mulching, or nearby felling) increased butterfly richness and abundance within 1–4 years compared to unmanaged woodland or before management, while a thinned forest had similar fruit-feeding butterfly richness and abundance to an unmanaged regenerating forest, and partially cleared plots showed higher butterfly but lower moth richness than closed-canopy plots (3940). Coppiced woodland supported different moth and butterfly communities than mature forest; butterfly richness and abundance were higher in coppiced than unmanaged woodland and tended to be greater in more recently coppiced stands (e.g., 2–7 or 12–15 years since cutting) than in older (>15 years) stands; macro-moths had lower richness and abundance in coppiced than in mature forest and did not vary consistently with coppice age (3939).

question_details.query: How does rotational burning compare to leaving unburned patches during prescribed fires for butterfly populations in US prairies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from US prairies and similar open habitats shows that leaving unburned patches during prescribed fires was associated with increases in Karner blue butterfly abundance over 2–3 years, greater abundance for six of nine specialist species (with one lower and two similar), and confirmed use of all surveyed unburned patches by Karner blues [3879]. In contrast, rotational burning produced mixed outcomes: butterfly richness and/or abundance were sometimes higher than on unmanaged or annually burned sites, but often varied with time since last burn (generally higher more than 1–4 years after burning), and some taxa or regions showed lower abundance under rotational burning than under other management or unmanaged conditions; specific results included similar Karner blue abundance to unmanaged sites, variable responses among fritillaries (including lower abundance for some species in some regions), and patterns where regal fritillary abundance was higher in prairies managed on a three-year rotation or four years post-burn than in more recently or much longer unburned sites [3883].

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Protect greenfield or undeveloped urban sites: In Singapore and Mexico, protected native forest and grassland in urban areas had higher butterfly species richness than urban parks or non-native Eucalyptus plantations [3836].

For selective (single‑tree) logging, a replicated, controlled, before‑after US study found moth species richness was similar to group selection and clearcutting, but lower than in unharvested forest (3867). For group selection and thinning, one controlled, before‑after US study found thinning produced higher macro‑moth richness than patch‑cutting or clearcutting and similar richness to unharvested forest; two replicated, controlled, before‑after studies found group selection had moth richness similar to single‑tree selection and clearcutting, with richness recovering at a similar rate to clearcutting and slower than shelterwood (3868, 3871).

question_details.query: What are the effects on butterflies and moths of different methods for managing linear features like road verges and power lines?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across power-line corridors, mechanical cutting and recent scrub/tree clearance were associated with higher butterfly species richness than unmanaged land, with richness highest 2–4 years post-clearance; abundance was higher than unmanaged in some cases, while time-since-management effects varied by species, and mowing versus cutting/herbicide produced similar abundances for several species except frosted elfin, which was higher with mowing; pearl-bordered fritillaries used areas cleared 1–2 years earlier but not ≥3 years earlier [3855]. On road verges and pavements, restricting or stopping herbicide use in restored roadside prairies was linked to greater butterfly richness and abundance and lower mortality risk than verges dominated by non-native grasses without restrictions; on transmission lines, unsprayed and unmown sites had similar butterfly richness but higher abundance of northern/pearl crescents than sprayed and mown sites, with similar total abundance [3899]. Altering mowing on greenspaces/road verges showed that less frequent or no mowing increased butterfly/moth richness and diversity; unmown parks and road verges/under power lines had higher abundance for all adult butterflies or for pearl/northern pearl crescents, while other species showed similar abundance; late-summer roadside mowing had more ringlets than mid-summer; less frequent or later mowing reduced numbers of butterflies killed by traffic; butterflies were recorded on verges mown once or twice a year and on unmown verges, but on mown verges they were only recorded where hay was removed [3841]. Restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along verges (e.g., sowing native wildflowers, increasing larval host plants, plant species richness, and flowering plants) increased richness and sometimes abundance of butterflies, day-flying and burnet moths compared to non-native dominated verges; wider verges had higher richness and abundance; in Canada, mown or unmown verges and power-line sites had similar richness and abundance to remnant prairies; mortality risk was lower on restored prairie verges than non-native grass verges, but more dead butterflies/moths occurred on roads with tall meadow verges and with habitat in the central reservation; less frequent or later mowing reduced roadkill; monarch parasite loads on mown verge milkweed were similar to prairies [3854]. Planting road verges with appropriate native species was associated in some studies with higher richness of butterfly/moth adults and caterpillars than verges with mixed or non-native plants, though other studies found similar adult richness, and effects on abundance were mixed [3842].
